resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Dishwashers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Commercial Dishwashers that are effective as of July 27, 2021. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_dishwashers/key_product_criteria.
columns_name: Idle Energy Rate for High Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines (kW)
Booster Heater Idle Energy Rate for High Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines) (kW)
Idle Energy Rate for Low Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines (kW)
Washing Energy Consumption (kWh/rack) for High Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines
Washing Energy Consumption (kWh/rack) for Low Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines
Pot Pan Utensil Machine Wash Area (ft2)
columns_description: A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
If the dishwasher claims the hot water energy offset, this represents the hot water energy offset in kWh/rack, calculated with Equation 1 of the Specification.

For all dishwasher types, the dishwasher is considered "in idle mode" when it is not actively running but is still powered on and ready to wash dishes at the required temperature. The idle energy rate is the rate of energy consumed by the dishwasher while “holding” or maintaining wash tank water at the thermostat(s) set point.
If the booster heater idle energy rate was able to be measured separately (it is not inseparable), then this represents the booster heater idle energy consumption in kW.

Metric that represents the amount of water, in gallons, that is consumed while rinsing and sanitizing dishware in one hour by the dishwashing machine. This water consumption metric is used for single tank flight type and multiple tank flight type machines.

Metric that represents the amount of water, in gallons, that is consumed per one square foot of rack area while rinsing and sanitizing dishware. This water consumption metric is used for pot, pan, and utensil machines.

An operational setting that is designed to reduce energy during idle mode through temporary shut-down of certain machine components (pumps or belt motors) or reduction of certain temperature set points.

Describes the method for which the commercial dishwasher machine applies hot water or a chemical sanitizing solution for the purposes of cleaning dishware. Dual Sanitizing machines must meet both the high temp and low temp requirements.

Indicates if the product is claiming the Hot Water Energy Offset provided in Equation 1 of the Specification. The machine must meet the definition for Heat Recovery Machine in Section 1 of the Specification to claim this offset.
Designates the type of dishmachine model.
The following types of energy heat recovery features are possible: Exhaust Heat Exchanger; Wash Compartment Heat Exchanger; Supplemental Heat Pump; Drain Water Heat Exchanger; Other Energy Recovery.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

For all dishwasher types, the dishwasher is considered "in idle mode" when it is not actively running but is still powered on and ready to wash dishes at the required temperature. The idle energy rate is the rate of energy consumed by the dishwasher while “holding” or maintaining wash tank water at the thermostat(s) set point.

Metric that represents total washing energy, including any internal or external booster heater energy in addition to the tank, heat, motor, control, and any additional auxiliary energy, expressed in kWh/rack.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

"Warewashing equipment with heat recovery; a heat exchanger that recovers energy from other heat sources (i.e. waste water, exhaust duct) for the purpose of heating potable water. This includes but is not limited to drain water, wash compartment, and/or exhaust heat exchangers; and supplemental heat pumps. The equipment:
1) must use a minimum of 95% of water volume from the cold-water inlet for the wash and rinse cycle. The machine can have both cold-water and hot-water inlets, but a maximum of 5% of wash rinse cycle water shall come from the hot water; 
2) must have an inlet water temperature of 70 ± 3°F; and 
3) must operate at or above 180°F. "
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

Describes if the dishwasher has a booster heater that is inseparable.  A booster heater is a water heater that raises the temperature of preheated water 40 to 80°F. The preheated water is supplied to the unit [booster heater] at temperatures that are typically between100 and 140°F. This booster heater can be either integral to the dishwasher, or externally connected. The booster heater (internal or external) energy consumption shall be measured and reported separately, if possible. However, if booster energy cannot be measured separately it will be included in the idle energy rate measurements.

Metric that represents the amount of water, in gallons, that is consumed while rinsing and sanitizing one rack of dishware. This water consumption metric is used to qualify under counter, single tank door, pot, pan, and utensil, single tank rack conveyor, and multiple tank rack conveyor machines.
The racks per hour for this dishwasher.

Metric that represents total washing energy, including any internal or external booster heater energy in addition to the tank, heat, motor, control, and any additional auxiliary energy, expressed in kWh/rack.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
If a dishwasher has an energy saver mode, this represents the measured Energy Saver Mode Idle Energy Rate.
The wash area available for pot, pan, and utensil dishmachines.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Fixtures
resource.description: Please note, Ceiling Fan Light Kits are no longer included in this dataset. The Ceiling Fan Light Kit dataset can be found here: https://data.energystar.gov/Active-Specifications/ENERGY-STAR-Certified-Ceiling-Fans-Light-Kits/3zeh-haeu/about_data. Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0, 2.1, or 2.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Luminaires or the Version 1.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Downlights. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/light_fixtures/downlight_key_product_criteria .
columns_name: Energy Efficiency - Measured at the Source (lumens/Watt)
Energy Efficiency - Measured Outside the Fixture (lumens/Watt)
columns_description: This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Indicates if the lamp manufacturer claims that the lamp is dimmable and meets the requirements in the specification.

The appearance of the light is indicated by the Correlated Color Temperature (CCT) on the Kelvin scale. Lower Kelvin numbers like 2700-3000K mean the light appears more “warm” like incandescent; a CCT of 3500-4100K mean the light is whiter and higher temperatures like 5000-6500K would appear slightly bluer. Light appearance is indicated on bulb packaging.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
For fixtures with removable light sources, the shape of the light source.

The R9 value is not included in the Color Rendering Index (CRI) score but important for a light source to show red in objects with red in them, such as skin tones, natural wood tones, produce, meats, and artwork. Higher numbers represent more accurate rendering of red.

The ratio of real power that flows to the light source versus the amount of power actually consumed.  A light fixture with a lower power factor will draw more current than a luminaire with a higher power factor for the same amount of power consumed.
The aperture size in inches for recessed downlight fixtures.

Most fixtures are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some fixtures have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers, three-way, or photo cell controls. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product. For light fixtures shipped with ENERGY STAR bulbs, the special features may apply to either the bulb or fixture.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The light source technology utilized by the fixture: compact fluorescent light (CFL), light emitting diode (LED), or halogen.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Indicates if a recessed downlight fixture is insulation contact (IC) rated or airtight.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Non directional fixtures (with removable light sources i.e. GU24 base bulbs) are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures meant to put light on a specific application (e.g. recessed downlights, under cabinet lights, accent lights, cove lights) are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture.

The expected useful life of the light source. Measured differently depending on the technology of the light source. For example, LED lighting expected useful life is based on the estimated point at which only 70% of the original light output remains, while for older technologies, like fluorescent and halogen, estimated useful life is based on the measured median sample life.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

The quotient of the total light source/lamp luminous flux (lumens) emitted over the total lamp power input (Watts). It is expressed in lm/W. For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are residential only, considered "non-directional" and have been measured at the light source level.
Light sources can be fully integrated into a light kit or removable by a consumer by custom connectors, wire nuts, pronged plugs like GU10, GU24 or sockets e.g. E26 known as the Edison base.
The ENERGY STAR Manufacturing Partner is the organization that has signed an ENERGY STAR Partnership Agreement and labels the model. This organization is typically the brand owner.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Measured outside the Fixture (lm/W): The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W). For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are measured at the fixture level. This includes the following residential grade directional fixture types: line-voltage track lights, ceiling fan light kits, undercabinet and cove lighting, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface mounted and includes retrofit kits for existing recessed cans. This also includes the following LIMITED commercial fixture types: Accent lights such as line-voltage track lights, under cabinet task lights, portable desk task lights, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface-mounts BUT EXCLUDES typical commercial and industrial fixtures such as recessed troffers or linear forms (e.g. linear fluorescent pendants) typically used in office spaces.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
Total power consumed by the luminaire while in use.

A description of the "color" of a light source measured on the Kelvin (K) scale. CFLs are available in a range of color temperatures. Lower values (2700-3000K) mean the white light has a warmer (red-yellow) tone, while higher kelvin (4100-6500K) mean the white light has a cooler (bluer) tone.

The Color Rendering Index (CRI) of a light source represents the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature. The ENERGY STAR specifications require a CRI of at least 80. Incandescent lighting has a CRI of 100. Early fluorescent lighting had CRIs in the 60s, resulting in unpleasant appearance of skin tones.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
Indicates information on certification relevant to the consumer (i.e. product variations, unique issues concerning the model’s listing, etc.).
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. Average power consumption of CT Device + Service when in automatic sleep mode.
Lab tested accuracy of thermostat readout, compared with a reference sensor (⁰F).
Used to link Services that can be used with several different Connected Thermostat Devices.
Additional Models for Thermostat with equivalent lab test results, for example, variations in product finish.

An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
Describes the ability to communicate with Demand Response systems.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Clothes Washers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 8.0 and Version 8.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Clothes Washers that are effective as of February 5, 2018. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/clothes_washers/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Estimated Annual Energy Use (kWh/yr) for the dryer in a Combination All-in-One Washer-Dryer
Heat Pump Technology for the dryer in a Combination All-in-One Washer-Dryer
Drum Capacity for the dryer in a Combination All-in-One Washer-Dryer
Combined Energy Factor (CEF) for the dryer in a Combination All-in-One Washer-Dryer
Calculated Combined Energy Factor - Max Dryness Setting (lbs/kWh) for the dryer in a Combination All-in-One Washer-Dryer
Additional Dryer Features for the dryer in a Combination All-in-One Washer-Dryer
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
Estimated Energy Test Cycle Time (min) for the dryer in a Combination All-in-One Washer-Dryer
Paired ENERGY STAR Clothes Dryer Available
Energy Test Cycle Information for the dryer in a Combination All-in-One Washer-Dryer
Paired ENERGY STAR Clothes Dryer ENERGY STAR Model Identifier
columns_description: For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the estimated annual energy use is based on the Combined Energy Factor and an annual usage of 283 cycles per year, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Actual energy consumption will vary on your usage patterns, including how often your run the dryer, what cycle you select, and load size. NOTE: For gas dryers the estimated annual energy use is expressed in kilowatt hours to allow for comparison, and represents the equivalent multi-source energy use of the product (e.g., natural gas or propane typically expressed in British thermal units (Btu)).

Highly energy efficient heat pump technology typically heats, dehumidifies and circulates air in the dryer drum, so no vent is required. A Heat Pump model solely uses heat pump technology to dry clothes, while a Hybrid Heat Pump model uses a combination of heat pump technology and traditional electric resistance heating technology.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, this is the drum capacity of the clothes dryers in cubic feet as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Products with a drum capacity less than 4.4 cubic feet are considered compact.

A unique string of characters used to identify models with the same performance characteristics. This sequence is generated by certification bodies and is reported as a single row of data on the lists of certified products.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Integrated Water Factor (IWF) is a measure of water efficiency that considers gallons of water consumed per cubic foot of capacity. The lower the IWF, the more water efficient the clothes washer.

IMEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified clothes washers. The higher the IMEF, the more energy efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: ft3/kWh/cycle, and is calculated as the quotient of the capacity of the clothes container divided by the total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle, with such energy consumption expressed as the sum of the machine electrical energy consumption, the hot water energy consumption, the energy required for removal of the remaining moisture in the wash load, and the combined low-power mode energy consumption. For example, if a clothes washer has a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet and a total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle of 10 kWh/cycle, then the IMEF is 2.5.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
The height of the product.
The mandatory energy efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

CEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR clothes dryers; the higher the CEF the more efficient the clothes dryer. The metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Features applicable to the clothes washer may include Steam Cycle, Anti-Wrinkle, Gentle Cycle, Delayed Start, Sanitize Option, Hand Wash Cycle, and Supplementary Wash System.
This refers to whether the product is intended to be sold in the residential market, the commercial/multi-family housing/coin laundry market, or both.
The depth of the product.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the clothes washer under typical conditions, including the energy used by the washer and the energy needed to heat the water used by the clothes washer with an electric water heater. Unlike IMEF, the estimated annual energy use does not address how effective the washer is at removing moisture from the wash load and thus reducing the energy needed to fully dry a load in the clothes dryer. It is based on an annual usage of 295 loads per year, or around 6 loads per week, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of laundry done, the size of the loads, and the settings chosen.
The mandatory water efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rule-making activities and federal laws.

This is the estimated annual water use of the washer under typical conditions. It is based on an annual usage of 295 loads per year, or around 6 loads per week, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. Actual water consumption will vary depending on the amount of laundry done.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the Calculated CEF – Max Dry is a measure of the dryer’s energy performance in a more energy consumptive setting, namely the normal cycle with the highest dryness setting as defined in the ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2017 criteria. The Calculated CEF – Max Dry should not be directly compared to the CEF field, which is tested using the medium dryness setting, and represents a rated rather than measured value. The CEF metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, features applicable to the clothes dryer may include drum light, wrinkle prevention option, steam cycle, sanitization cycle, filter cleaning indicator, energy monitor/indicator, time remaining display, and supplementary drying system.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
This refers to whether the product is a combination all-in-one washer-dryer or laundry center.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the washer is done or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Clothes washers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill. For combination all-in-one washer-dryer products the washer and dryer must meet connected criteria.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the estimated energy test cycle time is the time taken to complete the test cycle necessary for ENERGY STAR certification. Products must complete the energy test cycle in less than 80 minutes in order to be certified as ENERGY STAR. The estimated test cycle time does not reflect actual consumer cycle times which vary as a result of load size, dampness, and composition.
Indicates if the clothes washer is being marketed as a matched pair with an ENERGY STAR Clothes Dryer.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the cycle selection and settings (temperature and dryness where separately selectable) as defined in the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2, Section 3.3, used for certification to ENERGY STAR.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
The width of the product.
Paired clothes dryer ENERGY STAR Model Identifier.
This is the tub capacity of the clothes washer in cubic feet, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product

Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
columns_description: Included in some refrigerators for making ice cubes.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will

The U.S. federal standard is the maximum energy consumption in kWh/year allowed by the U.S. Department of Energy for a refrigerator or cooler of this particular configuration and size.
Measured from side to side.
ENERGY STAR certified refrigerators and coolers must generally exceed the U.S. federal standard by at least 10%. This column tells you by how much each model exceeds the standard.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the refrigerator or cooler door is not closed or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Refrigerators or coolers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.
Classification of products by the type of energy used or by capacity or other performance-related features that affect efficiency. Different ENERGY STAR levels may apply to different product classes.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

This is a figure accounting for the fact that freezers require more energy than refrigerators per unit of actual volume, because they are colder. The adjusted volume is the sum of the fresh food compartment volume, the cooler compartment volume, and the product of an adjustment factor and the net freezer compartment volume in cubic feet. It is used to determine the federal energy conservation standards for refrigerators, freezers, and coolers. Adjusted Volume = Fresh Food Volume + Cooler Volume + (1.76 x Freezer Volume).

Refrigerator models listed with Connected Functionality must be tested using the ENERGY STAR Test Method to Validate Demand Response to verify the model’s Demand Response (DR) Functionality. Coolers are not required to be tested.
This is the type of defrost function. Automatic, manual, and partial automatic are the standard defrost types.
Allows access to ice and/or water through an exterior dispenser. Automatic icemakers and through the door dispensers offer convenience but they can increase energy use by 14-20%.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
This refrigerator or cooler design is approximately 24 inches deep without the door, making them nearly flush with standard kitchen cabinets. With the doors, they are generally 27-29 inches deep.
Designation for refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers, and coolers with a total volume of less than 7.75 cubic feet and 36 inches or less in height.
Built-in refrigerators are designed to be installed totally encased by kitchen cabinets.
This shows the configuration of the refrigerator or cooler.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for residential refrigerators include R-600a and R-441A.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kWh/year of the refrigerator or cooler under typical conditions. Your actual energy consumption will vary depending on how you use your refrigerator or cooler, such as frequency of opening and closing, surrounding room temperature, and how full the unit is kept. This figure is calculated according to U.S. Department of Energy test procedures.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
Measured from the floor to top of hinge.
The total interior volume of the refrigerator, including both the refrigerator and freezer compartments. Generally, the larger the refrigerator, the greater the energy consumption.

bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Geothermal Heat Pumps
resource.description: All ENERGY STAR certified geothermal heat pump models are recognized as Most Efficient, as they deliver superior performance, particularly when it is very cold or very hot. Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Geothermal Heat Pumps that are effective as of January 1, 2012 or the Version 3.2 Program Requirements that are effective as of July 16, 2020. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/heating_cooling/heat_pumps_geothermal/key_product_criteria.

Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

ENERGY STAR specification.

A geothermal heat pump uses the thermal energy of the ground or groundwater to provide residential space conditioning and/or domestic water heating. A geothermal heat pump model normally consists of one or more factory-made assemblies that include indoor conditioning and/or domestic water heat exchanger(s), compressors, and a ground-side heat exchanger. A geothermal heat pump model may provide space heating, space cooling, domestic water heating, or a combination of these functions and may also include the functions of liquid circulation, thermal storage, air circulation, air cleaning, dehumidifying or humidifying. A geothermal heat pump system generally consists of one or more geothermal heat pump models, the ground heat exchanger(s), the air and/or hydronic space conditioning distribution system(s), temperature controls, and thermal storage tanks.

The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

A measure of efficiency in the cooling mode that represents the ratio of total cooling capacity to electrical energy input.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Bulbs
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0 and V2.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Lamps (Light Bulbs) that are effective as of January 2, 2017. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/lighting_fans/light_bulbs/key_product_criteria
columns_description: Indicates whether the lamp meets the criteria to be recognized as connected.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

The Color Rendering Index (CRI) of a light source is a measure of color quality and represents the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature. The ENERGY STAR specifications require a CRI of at least 80. Incandescent lighting has a CRI of 100. Early fluorescent lighting had CRIs in the 60s, resulting in unpleasant appearance of skin tones.

The appearance of the light is indicated by the Correlated Color Temperature (CCT) on the Kelvin scale. Lower Kelvin numbers like 2700-3000K mean the light appears more “warm” like incandescent; a CCT of 3500-4100K mean the light is whiter and higher temperatures like 5000-6500K would appear slightly bluer. Light appearance is indicated on bulb packaging.
The reported angle of the light distribution at which the luminous intensity is 1/2 of the center beam (in degrees).
Center beam candle power (CBCP) the luminous intensity at the center of the beam, measured in candela (cd).
The maximum diameter of the light bulb in millimeters.
The familiar wattage of the traditional bulb that this efficient bulb can replace using fewer watts.

The shape of the light bulb. General purpose incandescent (i.e. 40W, 60W etc.) replacements include bare-spiral CFLs, and A-shape CFLs and LED bulbs. Globe or "G" type shapes are common for bathroom vanity lights, Reflector bulbs are commonly referred to as flood or spot lights and include R (reflector), bulged reflector (BR), parabolic aluminum reflector (PAR), multifaceted reflector (MR), etc. Decorative types include candle (C) shapes, and Other includes non-standard and less common CFL and LED shapes, etc.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The minimum light output level of a lamp when operated on a dimmer. Typically expressed as a percentage.

The R9 value is not included in the Color Rendering Index (CRI) score but important for a light source to show red in objects with red in them, such as skin tones, natural wood tones, produce, meats, and artwork. Higher numbers represent more accurate rendering of red.
A description of the reported light output, measured in lumens (not watts). To save energy, find the ENERGY STAR bulbs with the lumens you need, then choose the one with the lowest watts.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The amount of power that a connected lamp draws when it is not producing light but in standby mode.

A light bulb’s estimated lifetime in hours determined by operating a sample of bulbs according to industry test standards. For traditional bulbs like incandescent and CFLs the time that half of the test sample fails is considered rated life. For LED lighting the life is based on the estimated time for the product’s light output to decrease light 30%. By definition, some lamps will fail before their rated life and some will operate beyond their rated life. The ENERGY STAR specifications set minimum rated lifetimes and require extensive switching and long term testing to stress the products. Actual lifetime of products will vary depending on use.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
The electric power a light bulb needs to operate is designated by watts (W). For more information, visit our web page on this topic: http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=cfls.pr_cfls_lumens
The maximum length of the light bulb in millimeters.

The shape of the light bulb. General purpose incandescent (i.e. 40W, 60W etc.) replacements include bare-spiral CFLs, and A-shape CFLs and LED bulbs. Globe or "G" type shapes are common for bathroom vanity lights, Reflector bulbs are commonly referred to as flood or spot lights and include R (reflector), bulged reflector (BR), parabolic aluminum reflector (PAR), multifaceted reflector (MR), etc. Decorative types include candle (C) shapes, and Other includes non-standard and less common CFL and LED shapes, etc.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

The ratio of real power that flows to the light bulb versus the amount of power actually consumed. A light bulb with a lower power factor will draw more current than a light bulb with a higher power factor for the same amount of useful power transferred.
The measure of efficiency of a lamp, defined as the quotient of the total luminous flux emitted by the total light source power input.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Most bulbs are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some bulbs have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers or three-way control. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
Indicates if the lamp manufacturer claims that the lamp is dimmable and meets the requirements in the specification.
Indicates the nominal purpose of the lamp, omnidirectional or general purpose, directional, or decorative.
The connector at the bottom of the light bulb: Common base types include the “Edison” or “medium” screw base (E26), candelabra screw base (E12), and multiple pin bases (GU24, GU10) etc.
Whether the lamp is rated for use in enclosed fixtures.
The technology of the light bulb e.g. compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFL) or light emitting diode (LED).
Indicates if the lamp is capable of three way operation.
The method of communications or connected protocol that a connected lamp uses.
The number of years the light bulb is covered under the manufacturer’s warranty.

Indicates if the clothes dryer is being marketed as a matched pair with an ENERGY STAR Clothes Washer.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

The Calculated CEF – Max Dry is a measure of the dryer’s energy performance in a more energy consumptive setting, namely the normal cycle with the highest dryness setting as defined in the ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2017 criteria. The Calculated CEF – Max Dry should not be directly compared to the CEF field, which is tested using the medium dryness setting, and represents a rated rather than measured value. The CEF metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).

Features applicable to the clothes dryer may include drum light, wrinkle prevention option, steam cycle, sanitization cycle, filter cleaning indicator, energy monitor/indicator, time remaining display, and supplementary drying system.
The width of the clothes dryer.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

CEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR clothes dryers; the higher the CEF the more efficient the clothes dryer. The metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).
Paired clothes washer ENERGY STAR Model Identifier .

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Heat pump dryers require refrigerants as well. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower GWP alternative refrigerant options for clothes dryers include R-290.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The height of the clothes dryer.
The depth of the clothes dryer.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the dryer is done or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Clothes dryers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
Indicates if the clothes dryer is part of a laundry center.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

Highly energy efficient heat pump technology typically heats, dehumidifies and circulates air in the dryer drum, so no vent is required. A Heat Pump model solely uses heat pump technology to dry clothes, while a Hybrid Heat Pump model uses a combination of heat pump technology and traditional electric resistance heating technology.
This field is used to indicate the fuel type used to heat the air necessary to dry the clothes, either electric or gas.

The estimated annual energy use is based on the Combined Energy Factor and an annual usage of 283 cycles per year, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Actual energy consumption will vary on your usage patterns, including how often your run the dryer, what cycle you select, and load size. NOTE: For gas dryers the estimated annual energy use is expressed in kilowatt hours to allow for comparison, and represents the equivalent multi-source energy use of the product (e.g., natural gas or propane typically expressed in British thermal units (Btu)).

Venting Configuration refers to how the clothes dryer exhausts heated air. Vented clothes dryers exhaust the evaporated moisture from the clothes dryer cabinet using a vent which typically leads to a building’s exterior. Ventless clothes dryers use a closed loop system with an internal condenser to remove the evaporated moisture from the heated air. Moisture is discharged from the cabinet and instead collected in a reservoir or drained through a tube.

The estimated energy test cycle time is the time taken to complete the test cycle necessary for ENERGY STAR certification. Products must complete the energy test cycle in less than 80 minutes in order to be certified as ENERGY STAR. The estimated test cycle time does not reflect actual consumer cycle times which vary as a result of load size, dampness, and composition.

The cycle selection and settings (temperature and dryness where separately selectable) as defined in the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2, Section 3.3, used for certification to ENERGY STAR.

This is the drum capacity of the clothes dryers in cubic feet as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Products with a drum capacity less than 4.4 cubic feet are considered compact.

This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The Idle Mode Total Allowance is the maximum amount of power allowed in this mode for the model to be ENERGY STAR certified for the Level 2 option of a dual input model.
This indicates the No Vehicle Mode Input Power for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Input Power for the high and low illuminance conditions.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The No Vehicle Mode Total Allowance is the maximum amount of power allowed in this mode for the model to be ENERGY STAR certified for the Level 2 option of a dual input model.
Indicates which standardized protocol is used to send load management messages to the unit.
This indicates which, if any, network protocols that the model is shipped with, and None if the model does not have any network connected capability.
This indicates the maximum nameplate current in Amperes.

This indicates the Idle Mode Power Factor for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Idle Mode Power Factor for the high and low illuminance conditions.

This indicates the 15 A Operation Mode Total Loss for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.
This indicates the input voltage.
Indicates whether the model is able to connect to a network.

Indicates if the model has the transceiver and/or necessary hardware to support smart charging (i.e. beyond simple managed charging with pulse width modulation or CANBus) using any of these station-to-vehicle protocols.
The Partial On Mode Total Allowance is the maximum amount of power allowed in this mode for the model to be ENERGY STAR certified.
This indicates other features of this EVSE (e.g., vehicle to grid capability, Smart Home Energy Management System (SHEMS) compatibility, etc.).
The Partial On Mode Total Allowance is the maximum amount of power allowed in this mode for the model to be ENERGY STAR certified for the Level 2 option of a dual input model.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

Indicates whether the model meets optional connected criteria as defined in the specification, which may include functions helpful to the electrical grid (standardized signals and responses to manage energy use) and those helpful to consumers, such as scheduling and energy reporting.
This indicates which type of EVSE describes this model.
This indicates the number of outputs available for this model.
This indicates if this model is capable of the self-acting mechanism that controls the brightness of a display or lamp as a function of ambient light.

columns_description: Refers to the heating function found in certain room air conditioner models.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
The weight of the room air conditioner, not including packaging, in lbs (pounds).
The depth of the product in inches.
Most room air conditioners are installed on a windowsill. Some room air conditioners will straddle the window or straddle the windowsill.
Describes whether the product can participate in utility demand response programs without the home having a broadband connection.

The ENERGY STAR room air conditioner criteria covers both the casement-only and casement-slider product classes. Casement-only refers to a room air conditioner designed for mounting in a casement window. Casement-slider refers to a room air conditioner with an encased assembly designed for mounting in a sliding or casement window.
Describes the standards implemented in the product that provide privacy best practices and additional security by preventing or detecting network compromises.
The rated voltage of the room air conditioner, in volts.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as the ability to turn off the unit remotely when not at home and feedback on the energy use of the product. Room air conditioners with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kilowatt hours per year of the room air conditioner under typical conditions. This figure assumes 750 hours of compressor operation per year but will vary depending on the indoor and outdoor temperature and hours of use.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
Classification of products by the type of energy used or by capacity or other performance-related features that affect efficiency. Different ENERGY STAR levels may apply to different product classes.

The cooling capacity of the room air conditioner, in Btu (British Thermal Units) per hour, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix F. A higher Btu/hr means the product offers a greater cooling capability.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
An external communication module or device is required if communication hardware is not built into the unit.

Combined Energy Efficiency Ratio (CEER) is an energy performance metric for room air conditioners, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix F. The higher the CEER, the more efficient the room air conditioner. The metric has units Btu/Wh, and is calculated as the quotient of the cooling capacity divided by the average rate of electrical energy consumed by the air conditioner during operational and non-operational modes.

Room air conditioners with louvered sides are designed for mounting in a window, while units without louvered sides (also commonly referred to as "built-in") are designed for mounting through the wall of a building.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Room air conditioners with variable speed compressors are able to save a significant amount of energy during operation by continuously and quietly regulating the temperature. Room air conditioners with conventional compressors are either operating at maximum capacity when the thermostat calls for cooling or off when the desired temperature has been achieved and typically alternating frequently between on at maximum capacity and off.
The height of the product in inches.
This percent indicates how much each model exceeds the U.S. federal standard for its product class.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.
The width of the product in inches.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for room air conditioners include R-32, R-454B, R-290, R-600a, R-441A, R-452B, R-454A, R-454C, and R-457A.
Some room air conditioners require a support bracket on the outside of the windowsill for installation.
Indicates which standardized protocol is used to send load management messages to the unit.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Average power consumption of the unit when in automatic sleep mode.
The Hardware Architecture describes the type of module/device within or external to the system needed for connection.
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient noise performance requirement of 45 dBa in the lowest operational mode.

The Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio (SEER2) is the ratio of the total heat removed from the conditioned space during the annual cooling season to the total electrical energy consumed by the air conditioner or heat pump during the same season, expressed in Btu/Wh using 10 CFR part 430, Subpart B, Appendix M1 – Section 3.6 Heating mode tests for Different Types of Heat Pumps, Including Heating-Only Heat Pumps.

A Single Package unit is any central air conditioner that has all major assemblies enclosed in one cabinet. A Split System is any central air conditioner that has two separate assemblies, including an indoor coil and an outdoor coil.
Central air conditioners or heat pumps without an integrated blower fan will be tested with a furnace. Products are only ENERGY STAR certified in combination with the listed furnace.

The Energy Efficiency Ratio (EER2) is the ratio of the produced cooling effect of an air conditioner or heat pump to its net work input, expressed in Btu/watt-hour using 10 CFR part 430, Subpart B, Appendix M1 – Section 3.6 Heating mode tests for Different Types of Heat Pumps, Including Heating-Only Heat Pumps.

The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W). For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are considered directional and are measured at the fixture level. This includes the following residential grade directional fixture types: line-voltage track lights, ceiling fan light kits, undercabinet and cove lighting, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface mounted and includes retrofit kits for existing recessed cans. This also includes the following LIMITED commercial fixture types: Accent lights such as line-voltage track lights, under cabinet task lights, portable desk task lights, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface-mounts BUT EXCLUDES typical commercial and industrial fixtures such as recessed troffers or linear forms (e.g. linear fluorescent pendants) typically used in office spaces.

Efficacy is calculated by using airflow and fan motor electrical power values as tested per the requirements of this specification. Fan motor electrical usage is the only energy consumption considered for the fan efficacy calculation. Energy used for other fan auxiliaries (e.g., lights, sensors, heaters, timers, or night lights) is not included in the determination of fan efficacy.

Efficacy is calculated by using airflow and fan motor electrical power values as tested per the requirements of this specification. Fan motor electrical usage is the only energy consumption considered for the fan efficacy calculation. Energy used for other fan auxiliaries (e.g., lights, sensors, heaters, timers, or night lights) is not included in the determination of fan efficacy.

The expected useful life of the light source. Measured differently depending on the technology of the light source. For example, LED lighting expected useful life is based on the estimated point at which only 70% of the original light output remains, while for older technologies, like fluorescent and halogen, estimated useful life is based on the measured median sample life.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

Efficacy is calculated by using airflow and fan motor electrical power values as tested per the requirements of this specification. It is standard industry practice to round down airflow to the nearest 10 cfm when publishing this metric in product directories as the Airflow Certified Rating. For this reason, Airflow Certified Rating and As-Tested Airflow may occasionally differ on this list. In the case of a range hood, Airflow Certified Rating represents performance at working speed, while in the case of a bathroom or utility room fan, or an in-line ventilating fan, it represents maximum speed.
Residential bath and utility ventilating fans and range hoods must meet maximum allowable sound levels between 2-3 sones. There are no sound requirements for single or multi-port in-line fans.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

Total power consumed by the luminaire while in use.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
This measurement showcases the sound performance of a fan that is installed and operating under a heavier load than it is designed for.

Measure of the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. Indicates if the unit includes a light source.

Most fixtures are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some fixtures have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers, three-way, or photo cell controls. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.
This column indicates alternate ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) number(s) for the ENERGY STAR lamps that are shipped with the certified ventilating fan.
Ratio of real power flowing to the lamp to the apparent power in the circuit. A lamp with a lower power factor will draw more current than a lamp with a higher power factor of the same wattage.
The light source technology utilized by the fixture: compact fluorescent light (CFL), light emitting diode (LED), or halogen.
The number of speeds available for a ventilating fan. For fans with three or more speeds, only 3 is displayed.
Some in-line fans are shipped with a filter. The minimum efficiency reporting value (MERV) rating indicates the level of filtration. A higher MERV rating means a greater level of filtration.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Non directional fixtures (with removable light sources i.e. GU24 base bulbs) are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures meant to put light on a specific application (e.g. recessed downlights, under cabinet lights, accent lights, cove lights) are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture.
This measurement showcases the airflow performance of a fan that is installed and operating under a heavier load than it is designed for.

Indicates if the model has the through-the-door ice feature. It does not indicate whether or not the model has an ice maker. Please contact the manufacturer directly to determine if the model has an ice maker.
Classification of products by the type of energy used or by capacity or other performance-related features that affect efficiency. Different ENERGY STAR levels may apply to different product classes.

Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for residential freezers include R-600a and R-441A.

Freezers are available in both chest and upright configurations. An upright freezer has a front-mounted door like a refrigerator and shelves that allow for easy organization. A chest freezer typically requires more floor space, but they are also more energy efficient and since the door opens from the top it will allow less cold air to escape.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Included in some refrigerators for making ice cubes.

Freezers are available with either manual or automatic defrost. Manual defrost freezers use about half the energy of automatic defrost models, but must be defrosted periodically to achieve the energy savings. Don’t allow frost to build up more than one quarter of an inch.
Built-in freezers are designed to be installed totally encased by kitchen cabinets.
Designation for freezers with a total volume of less than 7.75 cubic feet and 36 inches or less in height.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
ENERGY STAR certified residential freezers must generally exceed the U.S. federal standard by at least 10%. This column tells you by how much each model exceeds the standard.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kilowatt hours of the freezer under typical conditions. Your actual energy consumption will vary depending on how you use your freezer, such as frequency of opening and closing, surrounding room temperature, and how full the unit is kept. This figure is calculated according to U.S. Department of Energy test procedures.

This is a figure accounting for the fact that freezers require more energy than refrigerators per unit of actual volume, because they are colder. The adjusted volume is the sum of the fresh food compartment volume and the product of an adjustment factor and the net freezer compartment volume in cubic feet. It's used to determine the federal energy conservation standards for refrigerators and freezers. Refrigerator Adjusted Volume = Fresh Volume + (1.63 x Freezer Volume). Freezer Adjusted Volume = 1.73 x Freezer Volume.

The date that the model is available for purchase.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the freezer door is not closed or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Freezers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.

columns_description: An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The mandatory water efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique

IWF is the water performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified clothes washers. The lower the IWF, the more efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: gallons/cycle/ft3, and is calculated as the quotient of total weighted per-cycle water consumption divided by the capacity of the clothes washer. For example, if a clothes washer has a total weighted per-cycle water consumption of 20 gallons and a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet, then the IWF is 5.0.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the clothes washer under typical conditions, including the energy used by the washer and the energy needed to heat the water used by the clothes washer with an electric water heater. Unlike MEF, the estimated annual energy use does not address how effective the washer is at removing moisture from the wash load and thus reducing the energy needed to fully dry a load in the clothes dryer. It is based on an annual usage of 1,074 loads per year for multi-family and 1,483 loads per year for laundromat applications, or around 21 and 29 loads per week respectively, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of laundry done, the size of the loads, and the settings chosen.

The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The mandatory water efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rule-making activities and federal laws.
Type refers to whether the product is a front-loading washer or a top-loading washer.
Features applicable to the clothes washer may include Steam Cycle, Anti-Wrinkle, Gentle Cycle, Delayed Start, Sanitize Option, Hand Wash Cycle, and Supplementary Wash System.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance

by EPA.
This is the tub capacity of the clothes washer in cubic feet, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2.

WF is the water performance metric for ENERGY STAR qualified clothes washers. The lower the WF, the more efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: gallons/cycle/ft3, and is calculated as the quotient of total weighted per-cycle water consumption divided by the capacity of the clothes washer. For example, if a clothes washer has a total weighted per-cycle water consumption of 20 gallons and a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet, then the water factor is 5.0.
This refers to whether the product is intended to be sold in the residential market, the commercial/multi-family housing/coin laundry market, or both.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The mandatory energy efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

MEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified commercial clothes washers. The higher the MEF, the more energy efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: ft3/kWh/cycle, and is calculated as the quotient of the capacity of the clothes container divided by the total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle, with such energy consumption expressed as the sum of the machine electrical energy consumption, the hot water energy consumption, and the energy required for removal of the remaining moisture in the wash load. For example, if a clothes washer has a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet and a total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle of 10 kWh/cycle, then the MEF is 2.5.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

resource.description: All ENERGY STAR certified geothermal heat pump models are recognized as Most Efficient, as they deliver superior performance, particularly when it is very cold or very hot. Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Geothermal Heat Pumps that are effective as of January 1, 2012 or the Version 3.2 Program Requirements that are effective as of July 16, 2020. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/heating_cooling/heat_pumps_geothermal/key_product_criteria.
