resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Ice Machines
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Automatic Commercial Ice Makers that are effective as of January 28, 2018 . A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria is available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_ice_makers/key_product_criteria
columns_description: UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for commercial ice machines include R-290, R-450A, and R-513A.

Connected products may or may not enable open-standards connectivity. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" A product that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" A product that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.
The type of ice the ice maker produces. Options include batch-type (which include cube type ice and other batch technologies) and continuous-type (which include flake and nugget ice types).

The type of equipment category the ice maker falls into. The three categories include Ice Making Head (IMH), Remote Condensing Unit (RCU) with remote compressor, Remote Condensing Unit (RCU) without remote compressor, and Self-Contained Unit (SCU).
Indicates the refrigerant type used.
This summarizes the connected functionality capabilities if the model has connected functionality.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

The net cooling effect of ice harvested (Btu/lb) divided by 144 (Btu/lb), expressed as a percent. The Ice Hardness Factor for batch type machines is assumed to be 100%, but must be tested and reported for continuous type machine certification. (For certain models this may exceed 100%.)

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as load shifting, ice level sensor and Demand Response exit points. Commercial ice machines with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering electric bills.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

If the product type is RCU, this field provides the model number of the remote condenser unit that is to accompany the ice-making mechanism (i.e., what condenser the unit was tested with and qualifies for ENERGY STAR under).

The amount of potable water used in making ice, which is equal to the sum of the ice harvested, Dump or Purge Water, and the Harvest Water expressed in gal/100 lb [L/45.0 kg] of ice, stated in multiples of 0.1. Alternatively, the amount of water entering the ice maker per cycle can be measured.

The total energy input rate, stated in kWh/100 lb [kWh/45.0 kg] of ice. For continuous type commercial ice makers this reflects the measured energy consumption per 100 lbs ice, multiplied by the ice hardness adjustment factor. (For batch type commercial ice makers the ice hardness is assumed to be 100%, therefore no adjustment is needed.) For RCU (with remote compressor), total energy consumed shall include the energy use of the ice-making mechanism, the compressor and the remote condensing unit.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The gross weight of ice harvested, stated in lb/24 h [kg/24 h], stated in multiples of 1.
Provides guidance about what is needed to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Griddles
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 1.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Commercial Griddles that are effective as of May 8, 2009 or January 1, 2011. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_griddles/key_products_criteria.
columns_description: The ratio of energy absorbed by the food product to the total energy supplied to the griddle during cooking.

The maximum production rate of the griddle while cooking a specified food product in accordance with the heavy-load cooking-energy efficiency test, expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the griddle brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
Designates the depth of the griddle in ft.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Designates the fuel type used by the commercial griddle. Qualified commercial griddle models are either gas or electric.
Represents the surface area of the commercial griddle (width multiplied by the depth).

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

Designates whether the model is a single-sided or double-sided commercial griddle. A double-sided griddle has hinged upper griddle plates (platens) that swing down over the food, thereby cooking the food from both sides at once.
This column designates whether the model was tested in the single-sided or double-sided configuration.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

For gas griddles, this field expresses the rate of  griddle energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature. The idle rate is normalized based on the area of the (bottom) cooking surface.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
This field provides additional details as to the type of griddle plate used (e.g., polished steel or chrome ½-inch grooved plate).
This field demonstrates whether the product has integrated or add-on top platens. This impacts the testing of the models as single- or double-sided.

For electric griddles, this field expresses the rate of  griddle energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature. The idle rate is normalized based on the area of the (bottom) cooking surface.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

Designates the width of the griddle in ft. For qualification of a product family, the 3 ft. model within the product family can serve as the representative model. (If product family includes units smaller than 3 ft.; however, each additional unit shall be tested and qualified separately from its product family.)
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Refrigerators
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 5.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Residential Refrigerators and Freezers that are effective as of September 15, 2014 or the Version 5.1 Program Requirements that are effective as of August 5, 2021. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/refrigerators/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Percent Less Energy Use than US Federal Standard
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
columns_description: Included in some refrigerators for making ice cubes.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The U.S. federal standard is the maximum energy consumption in kWh/year allowed by the U.S. Department of Energy for a refrigerator or cooler of this particular configuration and size.
Measured from side to side.
ENERGY STAR certified refrigerators and coolers must generally exceed the U.S. federal standard by at least 10%. This column tells you by how much each model exceeds the standard.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the refrigerator or cooler door is not closed or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Refrigerators or coolers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.
Classification of products by the type of energy used or by capacity or other performance-related features that affect efficiency. Different ENERGY STAR levels may apply to different product classes.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

This is a figure accounting for the fact that freezers require more energy than refrigerators per unit of actual volume, because they are colder. The adjusted volume is the sum of the fresh food compartment volume, the cooler compartment volume, and the product of an adjustment factor and the net freezer compartment volume in cubic feet. It is used to determine the federal energy conservation standards for refrigerators, freezers, and coolers. Adjusted Volume = Fresh Food Volume + Cooler Volume + (1.76 x Freezer Volume).

Refrigerator models listed with Connected Functionality must be tested using the ENERGY STAR Test Method to Validate Demand Response to verify the model’s Demand Response (DR) Functionality. Coolers are not required to be tested.
This is the type of defrost function. Automatic, manual, and partial automatic are the standard defrost types.
Allows access to ice and/or water through an exterior dispenser. Automatic icemakers and through the door dispensers offer convenience but they can increase energy use by 14-20%.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
This refrigerator or cooler design is approximately 24 inches deep without the door, making them nearly flush with standard kitchen cabinets. With the doors, they are generally 27-29 inches deep.
Designation for refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers, and coolers with a total volume of less than 7.75 cubic feet and 36 inches or less in height.
Built-in refrigerators are designed to be installed totally encased by kitchen cabinets.
This shows the configuration of the refrigerator or cooler.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for residential refrigerators include R-600a and R-441A.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kWh/year of the refrigerator or cooler under typical conditions. Your actual energy consumption will vary depending on how you use your refrigerator or cooler, such as frequency of opening and closing, surrounding room temperature, and how full the unit is kept. This figure is calculated according to U.S. Department of Energy test procedures.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
Measured from the floor to top of hinge.
The total interior volume of the refrigerator, including both the refrigerator and freezer compartments. Generally, the larger the refrigerator, the greater the energy consumption.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Water Heaters
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 5.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Water Heaters that are effective April 18, 2023. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/water_heaters/residential_water_heaters_key_product_criteria
columns_name: Is Broadband Internet Connection Needed for Demand Response?
Upper Compressor Cut Off Temperature for HPWH (°F)
Lower Compressor Cut Off Temperature for HPWH (°F)
Primary Communication Module/Device Brand Name and Model Number
Max. Input Rate for Gas Products (Btu/hr)
columns_description: The Hardware Architecture describes the type of module/device within or external to the system needed for connection.
Describes whether the product can participate in utility demand response programs without the home having a broadband connection.
Indicates if a product is capable of responding to Set Point Adjustment and/or Relative Price Signal commands.
Voltage required for a heat pump water heater.
Volume is the capacity of the tank in a solar system, in gallons.

Indicates whether the model meets optional connected criteria as defined in the specification, which may include functions helpful to the electrical grid (standardized signals and responses to manage energy use) and those helpful to consumers, such as scheduling and energy reporting.
Indicates if a water heater is capable of storing and operating based on Time of Use rates
The type of vent used by the water heater: Atmospheric Vent, Direct Vent, or Power Vent.
Electric Input kW refers to the input wattage of the heat pump or supplementary electric elements.
Rated electrical input power.
Indicates if a Connected product responds with a Basic Load Up and/or Advanced Load Up.

Standard HPWH require 240 Volt service, but certain products are appropriate for installation on a 120 Volt, 15 Amp Circuit. Split-System heat pump water heaters are residential water heaters where the compressor, evaporator, and/or condenser are separated from the storage tank.
The limit to the system’s tolerance of freezing weather conditions.
The minimum amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 67°F rise.
Gallons/year refers to the amount of propane consumed by the water heater with a tested outlet temperature of 125°F.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

Solar Water Heaters are available in the following collector types: batch, flat-plate, and evacuated tube. Batch collectors heat water in dark tanks or tubes within an insulated box, storing the water until drawn. Flat-plate collectors consist of copper tubes fitted to flat absorber plates. Evacuated tubes contain a vacuum of space around the metal or glass tube.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Heat pump water heaters require refrigerants as well. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for heat pump water heaters include R-744 (CO₂).
Indicates which standardized protocol is used to send load management messages to the unit.
Sound pressure level as measured per the NEEA Electric or Gas-Fueled Advanced Water Heating Specification, in dBA
The water heater's width, in inches.

This field is used to indicate the type of qualified product: Gas Storage Water Heater, Gas Tankless Water Heater, Heat Pump Water Heater, High Capacity Storage, Solar with Gas Backup, or Solar with Electric Backup.

Draw pattern used per the Appendix E test method. For storage-type water heaters, draw pattern is determined by the FHR test. For gas tankless water heaters, draw pattern is determined per Max. GPM rating test. For all solar water heaters,  draw pattern is determined by collector size.
The OG-300 certification number is assigned by the Solar Rating & Certification Corporation.
Fuel type refers the kind of fuel the water heater uses to heat the water, either natural gas or propane.
Vent size 2 is the width or diameter of a second vent opening.
Requested if Product Type is Heat Pump. Include the ambient temperature above which the compressor cuts off and electric resistance only operation begins.
Indicates product model is eligible for federal income tax credits available under the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022.

Forced Circulation systems use a pump to circulate the water or other fluid from the collector where it is heated by the sun to the storage tank. Integral Collector Storage (ICS) systems, or “batch” water heaters, combine the collector and the storage tank into one. Thermosyphon systems have a separate storage tank, located above the collector. Liquid (which could be water or an antifreeze solution) warmed in the collector rises to the storage tank.
This field is used to indicate whether the backup to the solar system is a tank or is tankless.
The water heater's height, in inches.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
The maximum amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 67°F rise.
Vent size is the width or diameter of the vent opening.
System can communicate using these protocols for sending messages and requests, some of which work wirelessly and some with wires (open standard media/network layer).
Capacity of the tank, in gallons.
Maximum amperage
Electric usage per year per
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Required if Product Type is Heat Pump. Include the ambient temperature below which the compressor cuts off and electric resistance only operation begins.
Recovery efficiency refers to how efficiently the heat from the burner is transferred to the water in the tank.
The water heater's depth, in inches.
Therms/year refers to the amount of natural gas consumed by the water heater with a tested outlet temperature of 125°.
Auxiliary Input refers to the input BTU per hour rating of the backup gas water heater in the solar system.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
First Hour Rating is the amount of hot water (in gallons) a storage water heater can supply in the first hour of using water, starting with a tank full of hot water.

Solar Uniform Energy Factor (SUEF) refers to the energy delivered by the total system divided by the electrical or gas energy put into the system. A value of 99 indicates that under rating conditions, the system used no gas or electrical energy to heat water.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

Uniform Energy Factor (UEF) is the newest measure of water heater overall efficiency. It is a metric used to compare the relative efficiencies of water heaters. The higher the UEF is, the more efficient the water heater.
Refers to the total area consumed by the solar collector.

An external communication 
module or device is required if
communication hardware is not built into the unit.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
Volume is the capacity of the tank, in gallons. Storage Volume is not applicable for gas tankless, solar with gas backup, or solar with electric backup water heaters.
The rate at which energy is consumed by the gas water heater when running at maximum capacity, in BTU/hr.
Tank height is the distance from the bottom of the water heater’s tank to the top of its tank.
Height to vent is the distance from the bottom of the water heater’s tank to its vent.
Tank diameter is the width or diameter of the water heater’s tank.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Televisions
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 9.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Televisions that are effective as of October 20, 2022. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/electronics/televisions/key_product_criteria.

Is Automatic Brightness Control Enabled by Default in the Default SDR Preset Picture Setting When Television is Shipped?
Power Consumption in Standby Mode when Connected to a Network (watts)
Power Consumption in Standby Mode when Not Connected to a Network (watts)
Reported On Mode Power (per the Federal Test Procedure) (watts)
Maximum Average On Mode Power for Certification (watts)
columns_description: An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with uniqueperformance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and productspecification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certificationinformation from the certification body. Each row within the product list willhave a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track informationon certified models in their information systems.
This is the calculated average of the On Mode Powers measured for the TV through CTA-2037C, not the Federal Test Procedure.

A Television is a product designed to produce dynamic video. A TV contains an internal TV tuner
encased within the product housing and is capable of receiving dynamic visual content from
wired or wireless sources. 

Also included are Home Theater Displays (HTDs), which have screen size greater than 25
inches and do not contain an internal TV tuner.
This column tracks what is enabled by default in the Default SDR preset picture setting, not what is simply available to the TV.
The market for which the product is intended.
The most common display types include Liquid Crystal Display (LCD) screens, that are either LED direct-lit or LED edge-lit displays, or organic light-emitting diode (OLED).
The self-acting mechanism that controls the brightness of a TV as a function of ambient light.

The resolution format is defined by the number of physical lines along the vertical and horizontal axis of the TV. A TV is High Definition (HD) if the resolution is 1920x1080 pixels, 4K if the resolution is 3840x2160 pixels, and 8K if the resolution is 7680x4320.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

This is the Reported Standby-Active, Low Mode Power as measured per the Standby-Active, Low Mode Test Method referenced in Section 4 (Testing) of the Version 9.0 TVs Specification during federal compliance testing and is reported during the ENERGY STAR certification process.
The backlight technology used in the TV.
This is the measured Standby-Active Mode Power as measured per the Standby-Active Mode Test Method referenced in Section 4 (Testing) of the Version 9.0 TVs Specification.
This is the measured Standby-Passive Mode Power as measured per the Standby-Passive Mode Test Method referenced in Section 4 (Testing) of the Version 9.0 TVs Specification.
This is a calculated value that uses data obtained through the AEC Test Method referenced in Section 4 (Testing) of the Version 9.0 TVs Specification.
This value is obtained through the Federal Test Procedure during federal compliance testing and is reported during the ENERGY STAR certification process.
The diagonal screen size in inches.
The viewable screen area of the product, calculated by multiplying the viewable image width by the viewable image height.

The physical pixel count for the horizontal axis of the television (e.g., a television with a screen resolution of 1920 x 1080 (horizontal x vertical) would have a native horizontal resolution of 1920).
The physical pixel count for the vertical axis of the television (e.g., a television with a screen resolution of 1920 x 1080 (horizontal x vertical) would have a native vertical resolution of 1080).
This is the calculated average limit for the Average On Mode Power of the TV, which uses data from CTA-2037C, not the Federal Test Procedure.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Network connections, usually using Internet Protocol (IP).
The wireless band and frequency supported by the model.
Lists the features available to the TV in general (not just a particular picture setting)

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Dishwashers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Commercial Dishwashers that are effective as of July 27, 2021. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_dishwashers/key_product_criteria.
columns_name: Idle Energy Rate for High Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines (kW)
Booster Heater Idle Energy Rate for High Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines) (kW)
Idle Energy Rate for Low Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines (kW)
Washing Energy Consumption (kWh/rack) for High Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines
Washing Energy Consumption (kWh/rack) for Low Temp and Dual Sanitizing Machines
Pot Pan Utensil Machine Wash Area (ft2)
columns_description: A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
If the dishwasher claims the hot water energy offset, this represents the hot water energy offset in kWh/rack, calculated with Equation 1 of the Specification.

For all dishwasher types, the dishwasher is considered "in idle mode" when it is not actively running but is still powered on and ready to wash dishes at the required temperature. The idle energy rate is the rate of energy consumed by the dishwasher while “holding” or maintaining wash tank water at the thermostat(s) set point.
If the booster heater idle energy rate was able to be measured separately (it is not inseparable), then this represents the booster heater idle energy consumption in kW.

Metric that represents the amount of water, in gallons, that is consumed while rinsing and sanitizing dishware in one hour by the dishwashing machine. This water consumption metric is used for single tank flight type and multiple tank flight type machines.

Metric that represents the amount of water, in gallons, that is consumed per one square foot of rack area while rinsing and sanitizing dishware. This water consumption metric is used for pot, pan, and utensil machines.

An operational setting that is designed to reduce energy during idle mode through temporary shut-down of certain machine components (pumps or belt motors) or reduction of certain temperature set points.

Describes the method for which the commercial dishwasher machine applies hot water or a chemical sanitizing solution for the purposes of cleaning dishware. Dual Sanitizing machines must meet both the high temp and low temp requirements.

Indicates if the product is claiming the Hot Water Energy Offset provided in Equation 1 of the Specification. The machine must meet the definition for Heat Recovery Machine in Section 1 of the Specification to claim this offset.
Designates the type of dishmachine model.
The following types of energy heat recovery features are possible: Exhaust Heat Exchanger; Wash Compartment Heat Exchanger; Supplemental Heat Pump; Drain Water Heat Exchanger; Other Energy Recovery.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

For all dishwasher types, the dishwasher is considered "in idle mode" when it is not actively running but is still powered on and ready to wash dishes at the required temperature. The idle energy rate is the rate of energy consumed by the dishwasher while “holding” or maintaining wash tank water at the thermostat(s) set point.

Metric that represents total washing energy, including any internal or external booster heater energy in addition to the tank, heat, motor, control, and any additional auxiliary energy, expressed in kWh/rack.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

"Warewashing equipment with heat recovery; a heat exchanger that recovers energy from other heat sources (i.e. waste water, exhaust duct) for the purpose of heating potable water. This includes but is not limited to drain water, wash compartment, and/or exhaust heat exchangers; and supplemental heat pumps. The equipment:
1) must use a minimum of 95% of water volume from the cold-water inlet for the wash and rinse cycle. The machine can have both cold-water and hot-water inlets, but a maximum of 5% of wash rinse cycle water shall come from the hot water; 
2) must have an inlet water temperature of 70 ± 3°F; and 
3) must operate at or above 180°F. "
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

Describes if the dishwasher has a booster heater that is inseparable.  A booster heater is a water heater that raises the temperature of preheated water 40 to 80°F. The preheated water is supplied to the unit [booster heater] at temperatures that are typically between100 and 140°F. This booster heater can be either integral to the dishwasher, or externally connected. The booster heater (internal or external) energy consumption shall be measured and reported separately, if possible. However, if booster energy cannot be measured separately it will be included in the idle energy rate measurements.

Metric that represents the amount of water, in gallons, that is consumed while rinsing and sanitizing one rack of dishware. This water consumption metric is used to qualify under counter, single tank door, pot, pan, and utensil, single tank rack conveyor, and multiple tank rack conveyor machines.
The racks per hour for this dishwasher.

Metric that represents total washing energy, including any internal or external booster heater energy in addition to the tank, heat, motor, control, and any additional auxiliary energy, expressed in kWh/rack.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
If a dishwasher has an energy saver mode, this represents the measured Energy Saver Mode Idle Energy Rate.
The wash area available for pot, pan, and utensil dishmachines.

The type(s) of power supply unit(s) installed.  A Power Supply Unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac or dc input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a storage product. A storage PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the system and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection.  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's type will be separated by a semicolon.

The ready idle measurement for storage device 2 optimal point in GB per watt.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.

Automated Storage Tiering is the automatic movement of data between different types of storage devices. Tiering may occur within a single storage product or may span multiple storage products. For the purposes of ENERGY STAR certification, only tiering within a single storage product is applicable.

A configuration provided by the manufacturer may be optimized for the following workload types: transaction, streaming, or capacity.  Transaction is a workload type optimized for random I/O usage measured in I/O per second per watt.  Streaming is a workload type optimized primarily for sequential I/O usage, measured in MiB per second per watt.  Capacity is a workload type optimized for maximum storage as measured by GB (Raw Capacity) per watt.

A storage controller can be implemented in two different ways.  Scale-up storage is a storage product comprised of a discreet storage controller (with or without redundancy), which has a full view of all the storage devices in the storage product. Incremental storage capacity is added by the addition of storage devices under the control of the existing storage controller.  While Scale-out storage is a storage product capable of being comprised of two or more discreet storage controllers (with or without redundancy), combined with an overall integration or aggregation function resulting in a single storage product view for attached servers. Each discreet storage controller often has a partial view to a partition of the overall system's storage devices, but this is not a fixed requirement. Incremental storage capacity is added by the addition of storage devices under the control of the existing storage controller(s) and/or addition of additional storage devices along with additional controller(s).
Software operating environment/system name supported by storage configuration(s).

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Dishwashers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 7.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Residential Dishwashers that are effective as of July 19, 2023. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/dishwashers/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Capacity - Maximum Number of Place Settings
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
columns_description: Drying method(s) applicable to the dishwasher may include air dry, condensation dry, fan-assisted dry, heated dry, mineral dry, and/or automatic door release.
The maximum number of place settings as recommended by the manufacturer.
How much less water the unit uses per cycle relative to the U.S. Federal standard, expressed as a percent.
Tub material(s) could be stainless steel, plastic, hybrid, or other.
Product width.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
How much less energy the unit uses per year relative to the U.S. Federal standard, expressed as a percent.
The mandatory water efficiency standards for residential dishwashers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and U.S. federal laws.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
The mandatory energy standards for residential dishwashers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and U.S. federal laws.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.
The Hardware Architecture describes the type of module/device within or external to the system needed for connection.

Indicates whether the model meets optional connected criteria as defined in the specification, which may include functions helpful to the electrical grid (standardized signals and responses to manage energy use) and those helpful to consumers, such as scheduling and energy reporting.

Type refers to whether the product is considered a standard-sized dishwasher or a compact-sized dishwasher. Standard-sized models can fit at least eight place settings and six serving pieces. Products that cannot fit those amounts are considered compact-sized models.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
Features applicable to the dishwasher may include hard food filter, self-cleaning filter, cycle status lights, 3rd rack, top controls, and/or front controls.
Product depth when the door is shut and not including the handle.

This is the estimated per cycle water use of the dishwasher under typical conditions, expressed as the number of gallons of water delivered to the machine during one cycle, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Subpart B, Section 430, Appendix C. Actual water consumption will vary depending on the settings chosen.
A soil-sensing dishwasher  means a dishwasher that has the ability to adjust any energy-consuming aspect of the normal cycle based on the soil load of the dishes.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Indicates which standardized protocol is used to send load management messages to the unit.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the dishwasher under typical conditions, including the machine energy used by the dishwasher during a dishwashing cycle, any additional energy used by a water heater to heat the water, and the energy used by the dishwasher while in standby mode. It is based on an annual usage of 215 loads per year, or around 4 per week, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix C. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on your usage patterns, including how often you run the dishwasher and what cycle you select.

The power mode the product enters after receiving a signal from a connected device or an internal stimulus. The product may also enter this mode by virtue of a signal produced by user input. The product must wake on receiving a signal from a connected device, a network, a remote control, and/or an internal stimulus. While the product is in this mode, it is not producing a visible picture, with the possible exception of user-oriented or protective functions such as product information or status displays, or sensor-based functions.

A color space is a defined range of colors. Well known color spaces include sRGB, AdobeRGB and DCI-P3. Color spaces listed here are fully supported (100% of the defined range) by the Display.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power drawn by the display in a room with bright ambient light.

The power mode in which the product is connected to a power source, and is not providing any On Mode or Sleep Mode functions. This mode may persist for an indefinite time. The product may only exit this mode by direct user actuation of a power switch or control. Some products may not have this mode.

A computer monitor that has all of the following features and functionalities: (a) A contrast ratio of at least 60:1 measured at a horizontal viewing angle of at least 85° from the perpendicular on a flat screen or 83° on a curved screen, with or without a screen cover glass; (b) A native resolution greater than or equal to 2.3 megapixels (MP); and, (c) A color gamut 32.9% of CIE LUV.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The range of color supported within the CIE LUV 1976 u' v' color space and calculated per Section 5.18 Gamut Area of the Information Display Measurements Standard Version 1.03.

The maximum On Mode power requirement for a Signage Display model with the given Screen Area and Maximum Reported Luminance to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in On Mode cannot exceed this value. Computer Monitors must meet Total Energy Consumption requirements.

The most common screen types include TN LCD, IPS LCD, VA LCD, OLED, and Plasma.

Display contrast ratio at 0 degrees from the perpendicular, expressed as a integer relative to 1 (e.g., 1000 means 1000:1).
Available methods of delivering content to the display.
Features enabled in the default tested Sleep Mode.
Features enabled in the default tested On Mode.

The HDR performance level for models that meet the VESA DisplayHDR CTS v1.0 Section 5.1 criteria. The model must meet the HDR performance level for all three white luminance criteria, including the 10% Center Patch Minimum Requirement (cd/m2), Full-screen Flash Minimum Requirement (cd/m2), and Full-screen Long-duration Minimum Requirement (cd/m2). N/A if the model does not meet the VESA DisplayHDR criteria.

The power mode in which the product has been activated, and is providing one or more of its principal functions. The common terms "active," "in-use," and "normal operation" also describe this mode. The power in this mode is typically greater than the power in Sleep Mode and Off Mode.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
Display contrast ratio at +85 degrees from the perpendicular, expressed as a integer relative to 1 (e.g., 1000 means 1000:1).
The visible area of the Display that produces images.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The rated or reported maximum power which the model can deliver via USB-C connection (W).
The date that the model is available for purchase.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The fixed physical pixel count of the display.
Is the Signage Display model tested as a Tiled Display System?

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The number of expansion slots available for Input/Output (I/O) Devices and/or Auxiliary Processing Accelerators (APAs).
The types of power saving features that require the end user to enable them.

An Auxiliary Processing Accelerator (APA) are computing expansion add-in cards installed in general-purpose add-in expansion slots.  The model name of APA #2 is listed if it is included in this configuration.

An Auxiliary Processing Accelerator (APA) are computing expansion add-in cards installed in general-purpose add-in expansion slots.  The model name of APA #3 is listed if it is included in this configuration.
The brand of the processor(s) installed in the product.
The model name of the processor(s) installed in the product.
A measure of the rate at which the processor executes operations in GHz for the configuration.
The number of solid state drives (SSDs) in this configuration.  A SSD is defined as a storage device that uses memory chips instead of rotating magnetic platters for data storage.
The number of rotational drives in this configuration.  A rotational drive is defined as a computer storage device which reads and writes to one or more rotating magnetic disk platters.

The power supply type can be either Single-output or Multi-output. A single-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Single-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs shall be no greater than 20 watts. A multi-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to more than one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Multi-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs is greater than or equal to 20 watts

Memory scaling in Capacity is done through a scheme known as input data caching (IDC). Indicate the Capacity workload efficiency score for this configuration. These values reflect the updated SERT Version 1.1.0.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The number of processors installed in the product's as-shipped configuration.
An error-correcting code (ECC) is a memory type which uses redundant data to allow for reconsturcion of data when errors occur.

The model or configuration number for the typical or single configuration of the qualified product family. It is defined as a product configuration that lies between the Minimum and Maximum Power configurations and is representative of a deployed product with high volume sales.
The number of blade slots populated on the chassis, for this configuration.

The model or configuration number for the high-end performance configuration of the qualified product family. It is defined as the combination of Processor Socket Power, PSUs, Memory, Storage (HDD/SDD), and I/O devices that represents either the higher-price or higher-performance computing platform within the Product Family.
The maximum amount of dynamic random-access memory the system can support, measured in GB.

If Yes, this submission represents a single server.  If No, this submission represents a product family which is a high-level description referring to a group of computers sharing on chassis/motherboard combination that often contains hundreds of possible hardware and software configuration.

A computer server with greater storage capacity than a standard computer server. As shipped, these computer servers support 30 or more storage devices. These servers differ from Storage Products in that they run computer server operating systems and software stacks.

The form factor describes the physical configuration of the product. Types of form factors for computer servers include tower or pedestal, rack-mount, and blade (half or full chassis.
The maximum number of blade slots the system can support.

A computer server designed with extensive Reliability, Availability, Serviceability (RAS) and scalability features integrated in the micro architecture of the system, CPU, and chipset. A thread is the smallest sequence of instructions managed by an operating system.
A measure of the rate at which the processor executes operations in GHz for the configuration.

The number of buffered double data rate (DDR) channels per Server/Blade/Node available in the configuration.  A buffered DDR channel is defined as a channel or Memory Port connecting a Memory Controller to a defined number of memory devices (e.g. DIMMs) in a computer server. A typical computer server may contain multiple Memory Controllers, which may in turn support one or more Buffered DDR Channels. As such, each Buffered DDR Channel serves only a fraction of the total addressable memory space in a computer server.
The number of dual in-line memory module installed in the product's  configurations.
The installed amount of dynamic random-access memory the system can support, measured in GB.
The number of solid state drives (SSDs) in this configuration.  A SSD is defined as a storage device that uses memory chips instead of rotating magnetic platters for data storage.

A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac  input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a computer server. A computer server PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the motherboard and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection. A power supply unit can be installed explicitly for power redundancy in this configuration.

The Storage-Workload has four different transactions, two random and two sequential transaction-pairs. Each pair
has a write and a read transaction. Indicate the Random workload efficiency score for this configuration.

Single-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs shall be no greater than 20 watts. A multi-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to more than one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Multi-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs is greater than or equal to 20 watts.

Sorting is one of the most common and important operations in computing. The SORT worklet sorts a randomized 64-bit integer array during each transaction. Indicate the SORT workload efficiency score for this configuration.

A buffered DDR channel is defined as a channel or Memory Port connecting a Memory Controller to a defined number of memory devices (e.g. DIMMs) in a computer server. A typical computer server may contain multiple Memory Controllers, which may in turn support one or more Buffered DDR Channels. As such, each Buffered DDR Channel serves only a fraction of the total addressable memory space in a computer server.

A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac  input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a computer server. A computer server PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the motherboard and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection. A power supply unit can be installed explicitly for power redundancy in this configuration.
The Compress workload implements a transaction that compresses and decompresses data. Indicate the Compress workload efficiency score for this configuration.

Sorting is one of the most common and important operations in computing. The SORT worklet sorts a randomized 64-bit integer array during each transaction. Indicate the SORT workload efficiency score for this configuration.

Memory scaling in Capacity is done through a scheme known as input data caching (IDC). Indicate the Capacity workload efficiency score for this configuration. These values reflect the updated SERT Version 1.1.0.

Memory scaling in Capacity is done through a scheme known as input data caching (IDC). Indicate the Capacity workload efficiency score for this configuration. These values reflect the updated SERT Version 1.1.0.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Water Coolers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Water Coolers that are effective March 23, 2022 . A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/water_coolers .
columns_name: On Mode Performance for Hot Water Draw
On Mode Performance for Cold Water Draw
Daily Energy Use (On Mode With No Water Draw) (kWh/day)
columns_description: A performance metric for efficiency of a product after hot water has been withdrawn. Higher OMP signifies higher efficiency.
Some ENERGY STAR water coolers offer sparkling, flavored, or alkaline water in addition to cold water.
A performance metric for efficiency of a product after cold water has been withdrawn. Higher OMP signifies higher efficiency.

"High Capacity coolers offer a greater volume of hot and cold water per hour, but use more energy. These products are appropriate for high-traffic spaces, like an office or commercial space.  Low Capacity water coolers offer greater energy savings, but produce less cold and hot water per hour. These products are a good choice for a home or other low-use application."
The amount of hot water a product can deliver at the required temperature, in number of exact 6 ounce cups per hour.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The required energy to maintain cold and/or hot water at appropriate dispensing temperatures for one day. This does not account for energy consumed after water has been withdrawn.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
The amount of cold water a product can deliver at the required temperature, in gallons per hour.

"Cold Only Units: These units dispense cold water only.  Cook and Cold Units: These units dispense both cold and room-temperature water.  Hot and Cold Units: These units dispense both hot and cold water.  Hot, Cook, and Cold Units: These units dispense hot, cold, and room temperature water."
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP)

"The source of water for the water cooler.  Bottled: A bottle or reservoir supplies water to the water cooler. The bottle may be either top loading, or bottom loading (typically contained within the base of the unit). Point of Use Tap water is supplied to the water cooler through a pressurized water source. Conversion-type: The water cooler can be supplied by either a bottle or tap water."
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.
Additional features may include connected capability, energy saving modes, or touchless dispensing.

For conditioned storage water coolers, thermally conditioned water is stored in a tank in the water cooler and is available instantaneously. For on demand water coolers, water is heated as it is requested, which saves energy, but typically takes a few minutes to deliver.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
Water temperature from the on mode with no water draw portion of the test.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Imaging Equipment
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 and Version 3.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Imaging Equipment that are effective as of October 11, 2019 and the V3.2 Program Requirements that are effective as of November 18, 2021. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/office_equipment/imaging_equipment/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Professional Imaging Product Ready Mode Power (W)
columns_description: The model number of the DFE. Again, the model number may be the same as or different from that of the Imaging Equipment product.

The DFE Typical Electricity Consumption (TECDFE) metric assumes 9 hours in Ready State five days a week and the remainder in Sleep Mode. DFEs without a Sleep Mode are assumed to be in Ready State 168 hours per week.
Annualized TEC of the DFE.
The average power of the DFE recorded while the main Imaging Equipment product is in Ready State.
The average power of the DFE recorded while the main Imaging Equipment product is in Sleep Mode, applicable to DFEs with network-capable Sleep Modes.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance

is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

A functional adder is a data and network interface or other feature that adds functionality to the marking engine of an imaging equipment product and provides a power allowance when qualifying products according to the OM method.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
A performance metric that indicates the energy required by a  Professional Imaging Product to produce an image once in its Production Mode. A lower number translates to a higher efficiency.
The power required by a Professional Imaging Product to maintain its Ready Mode.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

1) Large Format: Products designed for A2 media and larger, including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media greater than or equal to 406 mm wide. Large-format products may also be capable of printing on standard-size or small-format media. 2) Standard Format: Products designed for standard-sized media (e.g., Letter, Legal, Ledger, A3, A4, B4), including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media between 210 mm and 406 mm wide. Standard-size products may also be capable of printing on small-format media. 3) Small Format: Products designed for media sizes smaller than those defined as Standard (e.g., A6, 4”x6”, microfilm), including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media less than 210 mm wide.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Required for all submissions which contain remanufactured products. Indicate if the certified product or product family includes remanufactured products.
Indicates whether the product is a Professional Imaging Product.
Eligible product type include: printer, scanner, copier, fax machine, multifunction device (MFD), digital duplicator, or mailing machine.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The power measured when a product enters Sleep Mode, either automatically after a period of inactivity, in response to user manual action, or in response to external electrical stimulus.
The power measured when the product has been manually or automatically switched off but is still plugged in and connected to the mains.
The time set by the manufacturer prior to shipping that determines when the product will enter a lower-power Mode (e.g., Sleep, Auto-off) following completion of its primary function.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product, with the measurement taken after the product has been powered on and has indicated it is in Ready State.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product, with the measurement taken after the product has been in Sleep Mode for 1 hour.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product with the measurement taken 15 minutes after the start of a previous job.

A DFE is functionally-integrated server that hosts other computers and applications and acts as an interface to Imaging Equipment. A DFE provides greater functionality to the Imaging Equipment. A DFE offers three or more of the following advanced features: network connectivity in various environments; mailbox functionality; job queue management; machine management (e.g., waking the Imaging Equipment from a reduced power state); advanced graphic user-interface (UI); ability to initiate communication with other host servers and client computers (e.g., scanning to email, polling remote mailboxes for jobs); or ability to post-process pages (e.g., reformatting pages prior to printing). 

The manufacturer may be the same as or different from that of the Imaging Equipment product.

Typical electricity consumption (measured in kilowatt-hours) during normal operation over a specified period of time. Typical Electricity Consumption (TEC) is a method of testing and comparing the energy performance of certain imaging equipment products and focuses on the typical electricity consumed by a product while in normal operation during a representative period of time. The TEC metric is a proxy for a typical weekly electricity consumption. Please note: the TEC value should be used as a way to compare products' energy consumption values under a set duty cycle and operating conditions. Actual energy consumption will differ, based on how the product is used. TEC is not applicable to all imaging equipment products.

Whether or not a copier, fax machine, MFD, or printer has the capability to produce images on both sides of an output sheet, without manual manipulation of output as an intermediate step. 

A product is considered to have automatic duplexing capability only if all accessories needed to produce duplex output are included with the product upon shipment.
The maximum claimed monochrome (black and white) speed in ipm (images per minute) and mppm (mail pieces per minute) when processing the given media.
Whether the product's output is monochrome (shades of black and white) or color.
The marking technology of the product: direct thermal, dye sublimation, electro-photographic, impact, ink jet, high performance ink jet, solid ink, stencil, thermal transfer.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Clothes Dryers
